lens.lens_summary: This lens reveals how rescheduling friction, seasonal pricing opacity, and cognitive depletion from multi-step platform interactions create compounding dropout risk across the guest journey, particularly in the negotiation and active_lease phases where System 2 is most taxed and defaults most dangerous.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: This lens does not directly address the discovery phase. Nneka's call is about an existing guest (Brad) deep into his lease, and the conversation does not discuss how Brad originally found Split Lease. However, Kahneman's priming and associative coherence concepts reveal an important structural insight: whatever primed Brad's expectations during discovery (marketing claims about flexibility, ease of rescheduling, transparent pricing) will be tested against reality in every subsequent phase. If discovery primed Brad for 'flexible mid-term housing,' then any friction in rescheduling directly contradicts the primed expectation, triggering the System 1 violation response Kahneman describes: 'System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.'

user_state.emotional_state: Curious but cautious. System 1 is performing a rapid trust assessment of the platform based on first impressions. Kahneman: 'As surely and quickly as you saw that the young woman's hair is dark, you knew she is angry' -- the guest's first encounter with Split Lease generates an instant emotional impression that shapes all subsequent engagement.
user_state.knowledge_level: The guest likely knows they need flexible mid-term housing but does not yet understand Split Lease's model (proposal-based negotiation, nights-of-the-week pricing, host-guest matching). They may be comparing to Airbnb or traditional sublets.
user_state.commitment_level: Browsing. No investment yet. System 1 is in evaluation mode, looking for signals of legitimacy and relevance.
user_state.data_available: Minimal. The platform knows the guest arrived (referral source, landing page) but has no behavioral data yet.

reasons: If the discovery touchpoint (ad, referral, search result) primes expectations that the platform cannot deliver (e.g., 'book instantly' when the actual flow requires proposals and negotiation), the expectation violation will trigger System 1 rejection before System 2 engages.
Kahneman's cognitive ease principle: if the platform looks unfamiliar or requires explanation, System 1 flags it as effortful and the guest defaults to known alternatives (Airbnb, Craigslist).
The Nneka call reveals that even an active guest (Brad) struggles with platform mechanics. If the platform is confusing for an active user, it will be impenetrable for a first-time visitor.
dropout_risk.evidence: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, Plot Synopsis: 'System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.' If discovery messaging creates a model ('flexible, easy housing') that the actual product violates ('proposals, negotiation, rescheduling friction'), the guest's System 2 activates in skepticism mode rather than engagement mode.

key_quotes.quote: Ideas that have been evoked trigger many other ideas, in a spreading cascade of activity in your brain... yielding a self-reinforcing pattern of cognitive, emotional, and physical responses that is both diverse and integrated -- it has been called associatively coherent.
key_quotes.relevance: Whatever the guest encounters at discovery primes an entire associative network. If 'Split Lease' is first associated with 'flexible' and 'easy,' every subsequent friction point (rescheduling complexity, pricing confusion) contradicts the primed network and triggers cognitive dissonance.

key_quotes.quote: The question that is most often asked about cognitive illusions is whether they can be overcome. The message of these examples is not encouraging.
key_quotes.relevance: First impressions at discovery form a cognitive illusion that is extremely difficult to correct later. If the guest's System 1 labels Split Lease as 'complicated' or 'untrustworthy' at first glance, no amount of later evidence easily overrides that initial impression.

search.what_this_lens_reveals: The Nneka call reveals critical search-phase infrastructure problems from the guest's perspective. Bryant mentions that 'Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern' (10:17-10:27) and that availability matching is a core challenge. Brad's pattern -- a hybrid worker needing weeknight accommodation for 2-3 months -- represents the target guest persona. Kahneman's law of least effort predicts that guests who encounter listings with mismatched availability, unclear scheduling options, or pricing that requires mental translation between nightly and monthly rates will abandon search rather than invest System 2 effort to resolve the confusion.

user_state.emotional_state: Hopeful but efficiency-oriented. The guest is comparing options and will gravitate toward listings that require the least cognitive effort to evaluate. Kahneman: 'A general law of least effort applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion. The law asserts that if there are several ways of achieving the same goal, people will eventually gravitate to the least demanding course of action.'
user_state.knowledge_level: The guest understands their own needs (location, dates, budget, days-of-week pattern) but may not understand Split Lease's scheduling model (nights-of-the-week, 4-week cycles). Brad's usage pattern (weeknights for a hybrid worker) is described by Bryant as 'very popular' but the platform may not surface this as a searchable filter.
user_state.commitment_level: Evaluating multiple options. The guest has not committed to Split Lease specifically -- they are comparing across platforms and listings. Any friction in search pushes them to alternatives.
user_state.data_available: Search filters selected, listings viewed, time spent per listing. The platform can infer the guest's schedule pattern (weeknight vs. weekend) and budget range from their filter behavior.

reasons: Availability mismatch: Nneka's listing availability is constrained by Airbnb cross-listing. Brad's weeknight pattern may not align with available dates, but this mismatch may not be visible until deep in the search process.
Pricing format confusion: if listings show nightly rates but guests think in monthly budgets (as the journey map suggests with '4-Week Rent'), the translation burden falls on the guest's System 2.

Bryant notes availability matching difficulty (10:17-10:27): 'with some listing availability, it would require a guest to have Monday to Friday.' If the search interface does not let guests filter by day-of-week pattern, they waste effort evaluating incompatible listings.

Kahneman's attention budget: 'you dispose of a limited budget of attention that you can allocate to activities.' Each incompatible listing the guest evaluates depletes their attention budget, making them less likely to continue searching.
dropout_risk.evidence: nneka-call.txt, 10:17-10:27: Bryant explains that availability matching is difficult because 'with some listing availability, it would require a guest to have Monday to Friday as a very popular usage pattern.' This reveals that the platform has not solved the search-to-availability matching problem, meaning guests may search and find listings they cannot actually book.

key_quotes.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern, which we see... so there can be some difficulties there in matching with your listing availability.
key_quotes.relevance: This reveals a fundamental search-phase problem: the guest's usage pattern (weeknights) may conflict with host availability, and this conflict is not surfaced early enough in the search process. Guests discover incompatibility only after investing evaluation effort.

key_quotes.quote: With someone like Brad's usage pattern, I think that would be a really great fit for your listening because they're typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
key_quotes.relevance: Bryant is doing manual guest-host matching that the platform should automate. The fact that this matching happens in conversation rather than in search reveals a gap in the search infrastructure.

key_quotes.quote: A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion. The law asserts that if there are several ways of achieving the same goal, people will eventually gravitate to the least demanding course of action.
key_quotes.relevance: If searching on Split Lease requires more cognitive effort than searching on Airbnb (due to unfamiliar pricing models, unclear availability, or missing filters), the guest will default to the easier platform.

listing_evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: The Nneka call reveals that listing evaluation is where the guest's System 2 faces its hardest work: translating between pricing formats (nightly vs. monthly), understanding availability constraints, and assessing whether a space fits their specific usage pattern. Nneka's pricing discussion reveals that rates are seasonal ($1,170-$1,175 originally, higher now), which means the price shown on a listing may not be the price the guest ultimately pays. Kahneman's bat-and-ball insight -- that people accept intuitive but wrong answers when cognitive effort is required -- predicts that guests will misinterpret pricing if the listing page requires any mental arithmetic. The journey map shows the listing page displays 'nightly rate' and '4-Week Rent,' requiring the guest to compute whether this fits their monthly budget.

user_state.emotional_state: Analytically engaged but cognitively strained. The guest is simultaneously evaluating photos, price, rules, location, and host responsiveness. Each additional variable consumes System 2 resources. Kahneman: 'Effort is required to maintain simultaneously in memory several ideas that require separate actions.'
user_state.knowledge_level: The guest knows their budget, dates, and days-of-week needs. They may not understand how Split Lease pricing works (nightly rate x selected days x weeks), how seasonal adjustments affect their total, or what a 'proposal' means in this context vs. simply booking.
user_state.commitment_level: Evaluating seriously. The guest has invested enough effort to reach a specific listing. But this is the highest-risk evaluation moment: if the listing page creates confusion or requires too much System 2 effort, the guest will abandon rather than push through.
user_state.data_available: Full listing data (photos, price, rules, features, host info). The platform also has the guest's search history and filter selections, which could be used to pre-compute fit signals.

reasons: Pricing translation burden: the listing page shows nightly rate and 4-week rent. A guest thinking in monthly budget must compute: nightly rate x selected nights x 4 weeks = monthly cost. This is exactly the kind of arithmetic Kahneman's bat-and-ball research shows people get wrong.

Seasonal pricing opacity: Nneka reveals that rates change seasonally (original $1,170-$1,175 is now higher). If the listing shows one price but the guest's dates result in a different total, the price violation triggers System 1 distrust.

Proposal concept unfamiliarity: the journey map shows the guest must 'Create Proposal' rather than 'Book Now.' For guests primed by Airbnb's instant-booking model, 'proposal' introduces uncertainty. The guest does not know if the host will accept, counter, or reject. Kahneman: the uncertainty activates System 2 deliberation where System 1 expected a simple action.

Ego depletion from prior search: the guest arrives at listing evaluation already depleted from browsing and comparing multiple listings. Kahneman: 'if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.'
dropout_risk.evidence: nneka-call.txt, 03:33-04:26: Nneka explains her original rate was '$1,170-$1,175' but new dates are priced higher seasonally. This means the price a guest sees on the listing page may not reflect what they actually pay for their specific dates, creating a bait-and-switch perception even if unintentional.

key_quotes.quote: Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175. And that was, you guys asked her about one from, therefore I am not able to do that.
key_quotes.relevance: Seasonal pricing variation means the guest's evaluation is based on a price that may change. If the listing page does not clearly show how dates affect pricing, the guest's evaluation is built on unreliable information, leading to distrust when the actual price is revealed at proposal stage.

key_quotes.quote: More than 50% of students at Harvard, MIT, and Princeton gave the intuitive -- incorrect -- answer to the bat-and-ball problem. The bat-and-ball problem is our first encounter with an observation that will be a recurrent theme: many people are overconfident, prone to place too much faith in their intuitions.
key_quotes.relevance: If the listing page requires any arithmetic (nightly rate x days x weeks = monthly cost), a significant percentage of guests will compute incorrectly and make decisions based on wrong numbers. The platform must eliminate all guest-side arithmetic.

key_quotes.quote: The Guest navigates to the Host's listing. This page displays the full listing information including: Nightly rate, 4-Week Rent total, a duration selector dropdown, day-of-the-week selection showing which nights are included.
key_quotes.relevance: The listing page presents multiple financial figures (nightly rate, 4-week rent) and multiple configuration options (duration, days) simultaneously. This is the maximum cognitive load point in the guest journey -- exactly where Kahneman predicts the highest error rate and abandonment risk.

proposal_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: The Nneka call indirectly illuminates proposal creation by revealing what happens when proposals are poorly understood. Brad's rescheduling requests suggest he may not fully understand the financial and contractual implications of changing dates on an existing proposal. Kahneman's concept of the 'lazy controller' applies directly: the guest creating a proposal must make multiple simultaneous decisions (dates, duration, days-per-week, budget confirmation) that tax System 2. The journey map confirms this: the guest configures a duration selector, selects days-of-the-week, reviews calculated pricing, and then submits. Each configuration step is a System 2 decision that draws from the same depleted pool. If the guest has already spent significant cognitive effort on search and listing evaluation, their System 2 at proposal creation is operating on reduced capacity -- exactly when the highest-stakes decisions (committing to dates and money) must be made.

user_state.emotional_state: Committed but anxious. The guest has decided to pursue this listing but is now confronting the financial commitment. The proposal creation step forces System 2 engagement on pricing and dates, which may conflict with System 1's desire to 'just book it.' Kahneman: 'Self-control and deliberate thought apparently draw on the same limited budget of effort.'
user_state.knowledge_level: The guest now understands the listing details but may not fully grasp how their configuration choices (selecting specific nights, adjusting duration) affect total price. The proposal summary shows 'Price per night, Total price for the reservation, Price for the first 4 weeks' -- three numbers that require comparison and confirmation.
user_state.commitment_level: Ready to act but needs the process to be frictionless. The guest has made the psychological decision to proceed. Any unnecessary complexity at this point risks converting a committed guest into an abandoned session.
user_state.data_available: Full guest configuration: selected dates, duration, nights per week, calculated total. The platform knows the guest's complete intent and should use it to simplify confirmation rather than require further input.

reasons: Multiple financial figures at proposal summary: 'Price per night, Total price for the reservation, Price for the first 4 weeks' (journey map). Three numbers at the commitment point forces System 2 comparison rather than System 1 confirmation.

Ego depletion: the guest has already spent significant cognitive resources on search, listing evaluation, and configuration. Kahneman's parole judge study shows that depleted decision-makers default to denial. The equivalent for a depleted guest is closing the browser.

Uncertainty about host response: unlike an instant-book model, submitting a proposal means the guest does not know if they have a place to stay. This uncertainty requires System 2 to manage anxiety while also processing financial details.

The proposal creation flow in the journey map requires the guest to 'configure desired terms' -- this is a construction task, not a confirmation task. Kahneman's System 1/System 2 distinction predicts that construction is far more depleting than endorsement.
dropout_risk.evidence: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2: 'tired and hungry judges tend to fall back on the easier default position of denying requests for parole.' The equivalent in proposal creation: a depleted guest defaults to not submitting. The proposal flow must make submission the path of least resistance, not the path of maximum cognitive effort.

key_quotes.quote: A modal or summary view appears showing the calculated pricing: Price per night, Total price for the reservation, Price for the first 4 weeks. The Guest reviews these figures and clicks 'Submit Proposal.'
key_quotes.relevance: Three financial figures at the commitment moment violate the single-number principle from Kahneman. The guest should see one total that answers 'what will this cost me?' before any breakdown. Presenting three numbers forces comparison and arithmetic, which depleted System 2 handles poorly.

key_quotes.quote: Self-control and deliberate thought apparently draw on the same limited budget of effort.
key_quotes.relevance: By the time the guest reaches proposal creation, they have spent self-control on search decisions, listing evaluation, and configuration choices. The budget for deliberate thought at the commitment step is reduced. The proposal flow must compensate by reducing the cognitive demand, not increasing it.

negotiation.what_this_lens_reveals: This is the phase most directly illuminated by the Nneka call. The entire conversation revolves around the mechanics of rescheduling and price adjustment -- which are negotiation dynamics seen from the host side but experienced by the guest as uncertainty, delay, and potential price increases. Brad's rescheduling requests reveal that the guest encounters a negotiation process that is currently manual, opaque, and dependent on the host's willingness. Nneka states explicitly that allowing rescheduling at old rates is 'not working financially' (03:33-04:26), meaning the guest faces price increases when rescheduling. Kahneman's loss aversion and ego depletion concepts predict that a guest who invested in an original agreement and now faces renegotiation will experience the new terms as a loss, even if objectively fair. The guest's System 1 anchored on the original price; any increase triggers the violation response.

user_state.emotional_state: Anxious and potentially frustrated. The guest submitted a proposal expecting acceptance and instead faces a counter-offer or rescheduling negotiation. System 1 has already projected forward (I have a place to stay), and the counter-offer interrupts that projection. Kahneman: 'System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.' The counter-offer IS a model violation.
user_state.knowledge_level: The guest may not understand why the host is countering (seasonal pricing changes, availability constraints) because the platform does not surface this context. Brad's rescheduling requests via text suggest he does not have visibility into Nneka's pricing logic or availability constraints.
user_state.commitment_level: Invested but at risk. The guest has submitted a proposal and psychologically committed. But a counter-offer resets the decision, forcing System 2 re-engagement. If the guest is depleted, they may reject reasonable counter-offers simply because re-evaluation is effortful.
user_state.data_available: Original proposal terms, host counter-terms, delta between the two. The platform could also provide context (why the host countered, market comparisons) but currently does not.

reasons: Price increase shock: Nneka reveals original rate was $1,170-$1,175, new dates are priced higher. The guest anchored on the original price and any increase feels like a loss, even if the new rate is market-appropriate.

Communication channel fragmentation: Brad rescheduled via text messages to Nneka, not through the platform. Bryant notes the need for in-platform messaging (09:07-09:21). When negotiation happens off-platform, the guest has no record, no protection, and no clarity.

Replace vs. add ambiguity: Bryant asks Nneka whether Brad wants to 'replace or add' dates (07:22-07:45), revealing that even the platform team is unclear on the guest's intent. If the platform cannot distinguish these actions, the guest certainly cannot.

Ego depletion from prior phases: by negotiation, the guest has completed discovery, search, listing evaluation, and proposal creation. Their System 2 budget is severely depleted. Kahneman: 'ego depletion is at least in part a loss of motivation. After exerting self-control in one task, you do not feel like making an effort in another.'
Manual process creates delay: Nneka must be contacted, must check Airbnb availability, must decide whether to accept. Each delay point is an opportunity for the guest to find alternatives.
dropout_risk.evidence: nneka-call.txt, 03:33-04:26: 'It's not working financially to heat... Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175... I am not able to do that.' The host cannot offer the original rate for new dates. The guest (Brad) faces a price increase mid-relationship, which Kahneman's loss aversion research predicts will feel roughly twice as painful as an equivalent gain would feel pleasurable. This is the highest emotional risk point in the guest journey.

key_quotes.quote: That's the frustrating part about... I had to go through you guys because...
key_quotes.relevance: Nneka expresses frustration at the lack of self-service rescheduling tools. This frustration directly impacts the guest experience: Brad's rescheduling requests go through text messages and then through the Split Lease team, creating delays and uncertainty for the guest.

key_quotes.quote: If Brad was to add a book tonight, and add instead of like replace, is that something that you would be open to... it would be a different rate.
key_quotes.relevance: The distinction between replacing and adding dates has different pricing implications that the guest may not understand. 'Add' means a different rate than 'replace.' This ambiguity creates negotiation friction because the guest does not know the rules of the negotiation.

key_quotes.quote: Also have the ability to message with Brad. I know you have his number as well, but having some way to talk with Brad would be useful.
key_quotes.relevance: The platform currently lacks in-app messaging for host-guest negotiation. Communication happens through text messages and the Split Lease team, fragmenting the negotiation process and creating opacity for both parties.

key_quotes.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
key_quotes.quote: Activities that impose high demands on System 2 require self-control, and the exertion of self-control is depleting and unpleasant. Unlike cognitive load, ego depletion is at least in part a loss of motivation.
key_quotes.relevance: Negotiation is the most System 2-demanding phase of the guest journey. The guest must evaluate counter-terms, compare to original terms, compute new totals, and decide whether to accept, counter, or walk away. Each decision depletes motivation for the next. A guest who faces multiple rounds of negotiation will lose motivation regardless of the merits of the final offer.

acceptance.what_this_lens_reveals: The Nneka call does not directly address the acceptance moment, but it reveals by implication what must be true for acceptance to succeed. The journey map shows acceptance requires the guest to click 'Accept Host Terms' and confirm with 'Yes, Proceed.' Kahneman's framework suggests this should be the easiest moment in the journey -- System 1 endorsing a decision already made. However, the Nneka call reveals that the terms at acceptance may differ from the terms at proposal creation (due to counter-offers, seasonal pricing, or rescheduling), which means the guest's System 2 must re-verify at the moment that should be pure System 1 confirmation. If the acceptance screen shows numbers the guest does not recognize or cannot reconcile with their original proposal, System 1 flags a discrepancy and System 2 must re-engage, introducing last-moment doubt.

user_state.emotional_state: Relief mixed with residual caution. The guest wants to be done. System 1 is eager to confirm and move on. But if the terms have changed through negotiation, there is a lingering System 2 concern: 'Did I agree to what I think I agreed to?'
user_state.knowledge_level: The guest should know all terms at this point: dates, duration, total cost, host identity. But if negotiation was conducted partially off-platform (as Brad's text-based rescheduling suggests), the guest may be uncertain about which terms are final.
user_state.commitment_level: Fully committed. The guest has decided to proceed. The only risk is last-moment friction that converts confidence into doubt.
user_state.data_available: Final agreed terms: dates, pricing, duration, payment schedule. Move-in details pending.

reasons: Terms mismatch between what the guest remembers agreeing to and what the acceptance screen displays. If negotiation involved counter-offers or rescheduling, the final terms may surprise the guest.

Payment authorization at acceptance creates a financial commitment trigger. Kahneman: if the payment amount is different from what System 1 anchored on (the original proposal price), the discrepancy activates System 2 at the worst possible moment.

The journey map's 'Yes, Proceed' confirmation dialog is appropriate but must show clear, final terms. If it shows only a button without a summary, the guest must rely on memory of previous screens, which is unreliable after multi-step negotiation.
dropout_risk.evidence: split-lease-journey-map.md, Phase 4: 'The Guest clicks Accept Host Terms. A confirmation dialog appears: Yes, Proceed. After confirming, the proposal status updates to reflect mutual agreement.' This is the right pattern but must be paired with a clear term summary. Kahneman: 'System 1 continuously generates suggestions for System 2... If endorsed by System 2, impressions and intuitions turn into beliefs.' The acceptance screen must give System 1 a clear, correct impression to endorse.

key_quotes.quote: The Guest sees the updated proposal reflecting the Host's counter-offer: Updated nightly rate, Updated duration (now 10 weeks), Updated total price.
key_quotes.relevance: The acceptance screen shows 'updated' values, which inherently creates a comparison task. The guest must verify that the updates match what they agreed to in negotiation. This is System 2 work at a moment that should be System 1 confirmation.

key_quotes.quote: When all goes smoothly, which is most of the time, System 2 adopts the suggestions of System 1 with little or no modification. You generally believe your impressions and act on your desires, and that is fine -- usually.
key_quotes.relevance: Acceptance should be the 'when all goes smoothly' moment. The design must ensure that the acceptance screen generates a System 1 impression of 'this is correct and complete' that System 2 can endorse without deliberation.

move_in.what_this_lens_reveals: This lens does not directly address the move-in phase. Nneka's call focuses on rescheduling dynamics during an active lease, not the initial move-in experience. However, Kahneman's priming and associative coherence concepts predict that the move-in experience will be evaluated against the associative network built during all prior phases. If the guest's journey involved pricing confusion, rescheduling friction, or communication opacity, System 1 arrives at move-in primed for problems. Conversely, if the journey was smooth, System 1 arrives primed for a positive first impression. The move-in phase is less about what happens at the space and more about whether the prior journey primed the guest for trust or suspicion.

user_state.emotional_state: Anticipatory and primed by all prior interactions. If negotiation was smooth, the guest arrives with positive expectations. If negotiation involved friction (as Brad's experience suggests), the guest arrives with heightened sensitivity to any discrepancy between the listing and reality.
user_state.knowledge_level: The guest knows the agreed terms but may not know practical logistics: key handoff process, house rules in practice, host communication preferences during the stay.
user_state.commitment_level: Fully committed. Payment is authorized, move-in is scheduled. But first impressions at the physical space create a new System 1 evaluation that can either confirm or contradict the entire prior journey.
user_state.data_available: Move-in date, space address, host contact information, agreed terms. The platform could provide a move-in checklist or guide but may not currently do so.

reasons: The guest has already committed financially and logistically. Dropout at move-in requires cancellation, which has costs.
However, a negative move-in experience primes the entire active_lease phase for complaint and early termination. The risk is not dropout but quality degradation.
dropout_risk.evidence: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Marvels of Priming: 'Reciprocal priming effects tend to produce a coherent reaction: if you were primed to think of old age, you would tend to act old, and acting old would reinforce the thought of old age.' If the guest is primed for problems (from prior friction), they will notice problems at move-in. If primed for quality, they will notice quality.

key_quotes.quote: Priming effects take many forms. If the idea of EAT is currently on your mind, you are temporarily more likely to complete the word fragment SO_P as SOUP than as SOAP.
key_quotes.relevance: The entire prior journey primes the guest's interpretation of the physical space. A guest primed by a smooth, transparent process will interpret ambiguous details positively. A guest primed by friction and opacity will interpret the same details negatively.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: This is the second most directly illuminated phase. Brad is an active-lease guest whose rescheduling needs reveal the ongoing friction of mid-term housing. The Nneka call shows that active-lease guests need flexibility (rescheduling dates), transparent communication (understanding pricing changes), and reliable platform tools (not text messages to the host). Kahneman's ego depletion concept is especially relevant: a guest managing an active lease while also working a demanding job (hybrid workers are the target market, per Bryant at 11:27-12:03) is perpetually depleted. Every platform interaction during active_lease competes with the guest's work responsibilities for System 2 resources. The rescheduling process must therefore be near-zero cognitive effort, or the guest will simply skip it (leading to no-shows) or handle it through informal channels (text messages, which create no platform record). CRITICAL: The Guest Leases page and Stays Manager are the PRIMARY recurring touchpoints during active_lease. The guest returns to these every week. The Stays Manager tracks individual visits (Week 1, Week 2... Week 13+) with status badges (Not Started, In Progress, Completed) and per-stay actions (Review, Upload Photos, Report Issue). The Date Change section handles rescheduling with replace/add/swap mechanics, a Flexibility Score percentage, and fair market rate calculations. The Payment Schedule tracks every 4-week cycle with rent, maintenance fee, and damage deposit. This is the MOST USED part of the platform for active guests â€” it IS the product after acceptance.

user_state.emotional_state: Settled but vigilant. The guest has established a routine but remains sensitive to disruptions. Brad's rescheduling requests suggest his schedule is variable, creating ongoing micro-decisions about which nights to use. Each rescheduling decision is a System 2 task that draws from the same depleted pool as his work responsibilities.
user_state.knowledge_level: The guest understands their immediate situation but may not understand platform policies on rescheduling, pricing adjustments, or what happens when they miss nights. Brad's text-based rescheduling suggests he does not know the formal process -- or that no formal process exists.
user_state.commitment_level: Committed to the arrangement but not to the platform. Brad communicates with Nneka via text, not through Split Lease. His loyalty is to the specific living arrangement, not to the platform that facilitated it. This means the platform has failed to create stickiness during the active lease.
user_state.data_available: Usage patterns (which nights the guest stays), payment history, rescheduling requests, communication logs (if in-platform). The platform should have rich behavioral data but may not if communication happens off-platform.

reasons: Rescheduling friction: Brad must text Nneka, who must check Airbnb availability, who must go through Split Lease. Three intermediary steps for a simple date change. Each step introduces delay and failure risk.

Price surprise: Nneka cannot offer old rates for new dates. Brad may not know this until the rescheduling is processed, creating a mid-lease price increase that feels like a betrayal of the original agreement.
No self-service tools: Bryant is building a rescheduling tool (00:32-01:02) because none exists. The guest currently has no way to manage their own schedule through the platform.

Cognitive budget competition: hybrid workers (the target guest) are managing demanding jobs. Kahneman: 'Self-control and deliberate thought apparently draw on the same limited budget of effort.' Any platform friction during work hours competes directly with job performance, making the guest resent the platform.
Off-platform communication: Brad texts Nneka directly. When the relationship moves off-platform, Split Lease loses visibility, control, and the ability to protect either party.
dropout_risk.evidence: nneka-call.txt, 01:23-01:42: 'He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make a fist for another day... if I have availability.' Brad's rescheduling process is: text the host, hope she has availability, wait for confirmation. This is not a managed platform experience; it is an informal arrangement that happens to have been originated on a platform.

key_quotes.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
key_quotes.relevance: Brad's rescheduling is entirely informal and off-platform. The guest experience during active_lease is not mediated by Split Lease -- it is mediated by direct text messages with the host. This represents a complete platform failure in the active_lease phase.

key_quotes.quote: Brad and I had our contract ended in January or February... it's not working financially... the new dates are priced higher now.
key_quotes.relevance: Seasonal pricing changes during an active lease create a mid-relationship price shock for the guest. Brad agreed to one rate; rescheduling forces a different rate. This is the active_lease equivalent of a bait-and-switch, even though it is driven by market reality.

key_quotes.quote: We'll be working on basically just having a way to notify you. So you'll know when a request comes in and then from there you'd be able to either accept the request... a replacement would probably be a little bit simpler. And then in addition, maybe we'd give you an opportunity to set a new nightly price.
key_quotes.relevance: Bryant describes a rescheduling tool that does not yet exist. This means the current guest experience during active_lease has no platform-mediated rescheduling. Every schedule change is manual, which Kahneman's law of least effort predicts will lead to either abandonment of the rescheduling attempt or informal workarounds.

key_quotes.quote: We normally avoid mental overload by dividing our tasks into multiple easy steps, committing intermediate results to long-term memory or to paper rather than to an easily overloaded working memory. We cover long distances by taking our time and conduct our mental lives by the law of least effort.
key_quotes.relevance: A rescheduling tool must divide the process into the smallest possible steps: select the night to change, see available alternatives, confirm. If the tool requires the guest to compose a message, wait for a response, and then confirm new terms, each step is an opportunity for System 2 to disengage.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Pricing format mismatch compounds across the entire journey, creating cumulative confusion and distrust
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Nneka's call reveals original rates of $1,170-$1,175/month (nneka-call.txt, 03:33-04:26) but the platform displays nightly rates and 4-week totals (split-lease-journey-map.md, Phase 2). Kahneman's bat-and-ball research (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Lazy System 2) shows that over 50% of elite university students fail simple arithmetic under cognitive ease. Guests who must translate between nightly and monthly formats at every phase accumulate pricing errors and distrust. This is the single most pervasive cross-phase problem: the guest thinks in monthly budget, the platform speaks in nightly rates, and the translation burden falls on the guest's depleted System 2.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Off-platform communication fragmenting the guest experience and creating opacity at every interaction point
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Brad communicates with Nneka via text messages (nneka-call.txt, 01:23-01:42) and rescheduling goes through the Split Lease team rather than a self-service tool (nneka-call.txt, 02:00-02:17). Bryant acknowledges the need for in-app messaging (nneka-call.txt, 09:07-09:21). When communication happens outside the platform, the guest has no record of agreements, no visibility into host decisions, and no protection if disputes arise. This pattern creates compounding uncertainty: each off-platform interaction reduces the guest's trust in the platform as the system of record.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Ego depletion cascading across phases: each phase depletes the System 2 budget needed for the next
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Kahneman: 'an effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around' (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2). The guest journey is a long sequential chain of System 2 tasks: evaluating platform credibility (discovery), filtering and comparing (search), analyzing a listing (listing_evaluation), configuring and committing to terms (proposal_creation), processing counter-offers (negotiation), verifying final terms (acceptance), and managing schedule changes (active_lease). The parole judge study shows that depleted decision-makers default to denial -- the guest equivalent is abandonment at each phase transition. The existing element library (works-002) addresses this for the host journey; this lens confirms it is equally critical for the guest journey.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The 'replace vs. add' ambiguity in rescheduling reveals a broader pattern: the platform's action vocabulary does not match the guest's mental model
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Bryant asks Nneka 'if Brad was to add a book tonight, and add instead of like replace' (nneka-call.txt, 07:22-07:45), and Nneka confirms different rates apply. The guest may not understand this distinction or its pricing implications. Kahneman's concept of System 1 associative coherence (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Associative Machine) predicts that the guest's System 1 will not automatically distinguish between 'replace' (swap dates at original rate) and 'add' (new dates at current rate). The platform vocabulary must make this distinction explicit and effortless, or the guest will choose the wrong action and face unexpected pricing.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Availability opacity: the guest cannot see what the host can see (Airbnb calendar, seasonal pricing, willingness to reschedule)
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Nneka cross-lists on Airbnb (nneka-call.txt, 05:06: 'Airbnb. I have some of them today. If I worked, then it automatically updates on.'), and her availability on Split Lease depends on her Airbnb bookings. Bryant notes they have access to her Airbnb account to sync availability (05:44-05:54). But the guest has no visibility into this dependency. When Brad requests rescheduling, his success depends on Nneka's Airbnb calendar -- a system he cannot see and may not know exists. Kahneman: 'System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains' (Plot Synopsis). The guest's model is 'this host has availability on Split Lease.' The reality is 'this host's availability depends on a different platform.' This hidden dependency creates unpredictable failures that the guest experiences as arbitrary rejection.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The guest's usage pattern (hybrid worker, weeknight stays, 2-3 month commitment) is well-understood by the team but not surfaced in the product
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Bryant describes the target guest persona in detail: 'hybrid workers returning to office' (nneka-call.txt, 11:27-12:03), 'Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern' (10:17-10:27), '2-3 month commitments typical' (11:27-12:03), 'Brad's usage pattern would be a really great fit' (12:03-12:17). This knowledge exists in the sales team's heads but may not be reflected in the product's search filters, listing displays, or proposal defaults. The law of least effort (kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, Attention and Effort) predicts that if the platform does not surface this pattern as a first-class search and configuration option, guests who match it must do extra System 2 work to configure their search and proposals to match their actual needs.

sources_consulted.what_was_extracted: Rescheduling friction details, seasonal pricing dynamics ($1,170-$1,175 original rate, higher for new dates), off-platform communication patterns (Brad texting Nneka), replace vs. add distinction and its pricing implications, Airbnb cross-listing availability dependency, target guest persona (hybrid workers, weeknight stays, 2-3 month commitments), lack of self-service rescheduling tools, need for in-app messaging, host frustration with inability to adjust pricing on rescheduled dates.

System 1/System 2 framework applied to every guest journey phase. Key concepts used: cognitive ease and the System 1 trust gate (discovery), law of least effort (search), bat-and-ball arithmetic failure (listing_evaluation and proposal_creation), ego depletion and the parole judge study (proposal_creation and negotiation), associative coherence and priming (discovery, move_in, active_lease), the lazy controller and self-control budget (active_lease), conflict between automatic reactions and intentional control (negotiation), task-switching cost (proposal_creation).

Guest journey flow: listing detail page structure (nightly rate, 4-week rent, duration selector, day-of-week selection), proposal creation flow (configure terms, review calculated pricing, submit), negotiation flow (host counters by modifying duration/terms, guest reviews counter), acceptance flow ('Accept Host Terms' with 'Yes, Proceed' confirmation). Key interaction patterns: authentication cycle, avatar dropdown navigation, notification system, confirmation dialogs, price transparency at every decision point.

sources_consulted.source: library/elements.json (elements works-001 through communicates-007, looks-001 through looks-003)
sources_consulted.what_was_extracted: Existing element library is entirely host-journey focused, built from the andreas-call.txt lens. All elements use host journey phases (discovery, evaluation, onboarding, listing_creation, pricing, proposal_mgmt, active_lease, retention). No guest-specific elements exist yet. Strong coverage: pricing display (communicates-002, looks-003), trust architecture (communicates-003), phase transitions (works-001), ego depletion mitigation (works-002), cognitive speed matching (works-003), human-to-digital trust bridge (works-004). Gaps: no guest-specific elements for search, listing_evaluation from guest perspective, proposal creation from guest perspective, rescheduling/schedule management during active_lease, guest-side negotiation experience. The existing elements provide a strong conceptual foundation that can be extended to the guest journey, particularly the System 1 trust gate (works-001), ego depletion design (works-002), single-sum financial display (communicates-002), and pre-packaged proposal pattern (communicates-005).
